text: Most won’t care but watching day 1 of SCG you see [[!Hostage Taker]]  show up everywhere I’m UB decks.
For Standard.

I forgot about the "you may cast exiled spell" part for half of watching those decks. Then it made sense why so many people were playing it because they totes don't get it back. I don't know why I thought it was an o-ring effect
It is an o-ring if they don’t have open mana to cast the spell.
The SCG commentators said this can replace Gonti, but I see this as a worse Gonti, but I’m biased.
Yea, I think we look at things through a different lens than they do
I see the benefit of targeted, but Gonti’s a better blocker and they don’t get the card back when they die.
Yea, if you're not able to cast the thing you exile it's a [[banisher priest]]. If you do cast their thing though they don't get it back which is crazy good

attachments.fallback: Banisher Priest {1}{W}{W} // Creature — Human Cleric // When Banisher Priest enters the battlefield, exile target creature an opponent controls until Banisher Priest leaves the battlefield. (That creature returns under its owner's control.) // 2/2
attachments.text:
Creature — Human Cleric
When Banisher Priest enters the battlefield, exile target creature an opponent controls until Banisher Priest leaves the battlefield. _(That creature returns under its owner's control.)_
_"Oathbreaker, I cast you out!"_
*2/2*
attachments.title: Banisher Priest {1}{W}{W}

text: The other major upside, though is you can have multiple Taker’s out at once, so that’s a major upside when you can play 4 of them.
So I now see the benefit for 60-card decks.
True story
They're both great for their respective formats
Yeah I totally get how hostage taker is gross in standard. It’s often +3 resource advantage
I got blown out by two deadeye plunderers.
In a mirror control of sideboard I’d consider Unsummon against Hostage Taker. Let them pay mana to cast my critter and and bounce Taker in response.
But that’s probably why I don’t play competitively.
I’m in it for the yucks.
Unsummon is almost always value in standard. Biggest problem is most decks don't have room for something that just generates value
Or at least that's my impression. I'm in the same boat as Henry regarding not playing it remotely competitively.
The fact that I won 3 games at the one GP I did was shocking
Am I the most competitive player here (before I reformed)?
Was anyone else a filthy spike for a while?
<
Filthy, filthy spikes.
Not me
Me with my 1 whole career pro point
I was on that grind for years
Was it worth it?
Like way back revised era I used to blow apart my lgs tournaments, but we're talking like 1994 when I swapped strats on Usenet and everyone else was just running Air Elementals
I use to play competitively. Once i had kids i couldnt fnm and grind anymore
I wouldn't call it a grind, I played in my first GP in January and happened to do super well.
So i got into edh
I only keep up with modern and legacy, I don't play enough to throw money away on standard. And I hate the idea of chasing the best deck in a format
@Don a spike? I’m flabbergasted!
I had a 2100 constructed and 2050 Limited rating back in 2006
Yea, and now they're both 0
Those were the days. My Magic player rewards envelopes were fat af. I miss it
Now you have to actually play FNM to get rewards
I just got to the point where I hated losing but didn't enjoy winning
Yea, at that point it's probably worth stepping back a bit

Goblins of the Flarg and Digging Team? I'm guessing for Grenade?
Jesus
Flarg had mountainwalk

For me it's been a combination of my playgroup being on the same page and having lots of fun and then Commander to be a change of pace mentally. It's helped keep 60-card formats fresh and fun while being competitive
That's legit to feed it a bloodlust and a bersrerk
Yea man.
Especially in 1995 when you were mostly just throwing stuff at a wall to see what stuck
Looks like the old school list a buddy of mine is playing.
I remember having a pestilence/withering wisps deck with pro-black stuff for Type 2 tournaments that often won with Balance/Zuran Orb.
I came to MTG too late in life to be competitive. If I’d gotten into it in my 20s, things would probably have been different.
Then again, MTG didn’t release until I was 24.
and I was already married.
I was semi competitive, but didn't play major tournaments except for the one GP I made day 2 at around the end of my competitive run

This is pretty clever of John Avon and company: 
"If we hit £250,000 then the Unstable prints, which all backers are now receiving, will have Unhinged on the reverse."
They couldn't afford to increase the shipping weight, so made DF prints.
I didn't order one, but do the mats have the edging on them?
What edging?
Lemme find a pic
<https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/51FiSLAUVQL._SX355_.jpg>
Been seeing them like that lately and it stops that rippling mats tend to get
From the FAQ: "These are the same as standard Ultra Pro playmats. They measure 60 x 35 x 0.5 centimetres approximately and are rubber with a fabric top side."
Probably no edge then. Still, double-sided is clever

text: Or any commander that transforms, for that matter.
If you're playing Grimlock I'm not sure super specific rules interaction is that important :slightly_smiling_face:
Like any double-faced cards, for casting/graveyard, etc. only the front face matters.
The other side only exists on the battlefield.
Okay, well how about Ulrich?
Okay
Gonna guess you get both creature types?
So in this case it would only be autobots since the flip doesn't exist except otb
tails
Thanks bud
Time to roll-out!
When his is on the battlefield and trainsformed, though?
I opened two Ulrichs in my pre-release, and the fatpack I bought had a regular and a foil.
All four still sitting in my binder
"711.4a While a double-faced card is outside the game, in a zone other than the battlefield, or on the battlefield with its front face up, it has only the characteristics of its front face."
Dana, that's because he's a shitty card.
Dana, get'em out of that binder...they're taking up precious space for decent cards.
When they spoiled him, I legitimately thought they had designed him for limited.
Shocked when they said he was for Commander players.
That is one of their most tone-deaf responses to EDH players in the last couple of years.
Maro was genuinely surprised EDH players weren't happy with it
"But guys, it's a two-color werewolf legend. It's perfect!"
Yeah...but then he never tried it in an Commander deck, did he?
I blame more the folks around him that should have known better.
I blame development.
I blame the schools
If you mean to design a werewolf commander for EDH, it MUST be able to transform your other werewolves.
There's a lot of of blame to go around when Immerwolf is a better commander
Werewolves can't work in EDH otherwise.
[[moonmist]]

text: Ruric Thar isn't terrible
Xenagod, but he's kinda good in pretty much any gruul configuration
You will only put werewolves in a werewolf deck...so you want your commander to be a werewolf.
Grafwidow isn't that great with spiders, either
But she's at least playable
No, but at least she has some synergies
That's correct
what's real bad about ulrich is taht he doesn't even interact with the shadows werewolfs all that well
He's an alpha werewolf that can't attack other werewolves.
I mean, even giving him Moonmist as an activated ability...would that just make him too OP? Werewolves?
Make it so he has to tap or something...just, something beyond a werewolf that is at the mercy of 3 other players to transform.
Nothing I love better than having my general's abilities controlled by my opponents.
And not even controlled. People aren't gonna intentionally control it. It's gonna be entirely random. So your abilities are randomly controlled by your opponents which somehow makes it worse.
Yup. The whole punisher mechanic dilemma.
Yup. The whole punisher mechanic dilemma.

Huh, duplicate message. Neat.

Ulrich is terrible, Ludevic is terrible. The only saving grace for werewolves are that they’re incredibly popular, Innistrad is incredibly popular, and we still have some other pack alphas to see.
If there’s any solace, the other alphas, Skaharra and Tovolar, are still really interesting
Werewolves are popular for flavor but not power...

That's why the Uninterested sets bug me; it's sucking up a slot where we could get Planechase or Archenemy or another Conspiracy to get more lore characters we might not otherwise see for quite a few years.
But it's not all about me, so hopefully the fans of it get a cool set.

Honestly I’m not even thinking of Unstable as taking up a release slot. It’s just a bonus for the fans. We already have gotten a ton of product this year as is. Archenemy as our non-commander supplement, two masters sets, etc.
My only problem is it’s a release we can’t use in EDH, which is pretty rare.

I have a feeling we're going to see standard have more EDH goodies than usual moving forward. Maybe I'm reading too much into Ixalan, but it just feels like the kind of thing a new CEO would implement when looking at sales numbers
*I* certainly would be at any rate.

It’d make sense
Each set has about five rare slots that were taken up by generic “intro rares” and now those aren’t necessarily needed (although we still get rares that feel like it.)

There’s really no harm in planting cards for EDH either. Development aims cards for standard, for other formats, and stuff
And financially why wouldn't you want your standard product to be as attractive as possible to as many groups as possible?
Maro has always been a bit of an old man yelling at clouds about Commander
And we're all old men yelling at clouds about standard

I'm one of those fans of the un-sets. It is really hard to get a group together to play it though. Most of the time it's one or two people buying the product and other just joining for the fun. I think a lower price point would do wonders to help the un-sets. 
Ixalans best new improvement is how they're treating mythics, which is to say they're not all powerful ultra secret rare qualities like Yugioh.

We give Maro a lot of shit about how he doesn't get Commander, but he's not responsible for Ludevic. Or the Invocation frame. Or MTGO. He's design, not development, so he's also not responsible for Shaleeli Cat or Hostage Taker errata. He's responsible for keeping color pie breaks down, which is super difficult when idiots start printing Chaos Warps and Hornet Queens without his knowledge (flavorful cards, yes, but they're breaks, and arguing against that is as dumb as arguing to abolish the RL). There are a ton of people at that company all pulling nebulous creative elements in a thousand different directions. Maro's not George Lucas, holding the reins of the prequels all to himself. He's a guy doing a damn good job for a group of perennially unsatisfied nerds that will find flaws no matter what the product. Ulrich is an enormous failure, but at least we know he's listening.

Conspiracy was such fun draft that to me it obsoleted the need for Un-sets by being a great goofy draft environment while also providing cool new cars and reprints. Un-sets have less utility with more dad jokes.
Maro gets a ton of undeserved heat for sure

[[!Patron of the Vein]] is a better [[!Noxious Gearhulk]]. Discuss.
It's my friend Hans so you should play it
But it's just better, right?
Same cost, evasion, one less point of power, exiles instead of destroys, and all other creatures that would be destroyed get exiled instead.
menace is evasion
Gearhulk has evasion as well and being an artifact creature is generally a better creature type than vampire in more decks.
Gearhulk does to disenchant. /thread
Right, my point was that they both have evasion
Yea I dunno. Both are sweet

I agree there...the exile is more often relevant against a lot of decks, so having gy hate on a stick demands an answer. The Gearhulk probably doesn't demand spot removal the same way the Patron does.
And Patron keeps getting bigger.
If you're not in a lifegain-matters or artifact deck, the patron is probably better overall.
or a gy-based deck...because if someone clones or controls your Patron and starts killing your critters...
Patron is much more of a double-edged sword. If someone kills my gearhulk by cloning it, no biggie...I got the benefit and can likely bring it back.
Probably meta-specific call there.
I might put it in Korlash
Is it a voltron deck?
Sorcery speed removal isn't great, but turning all of my kill effects to exile effects is probably too good to pass up
Yes
I think I'm running maybe four creatures besides my commander
Hey, if you play Vedalken Orrery, you can get rid of that sorcery-speed limit...
